text:
RUNA KHAN: However, for me,
the most important thing

is this code of ethics
that friendship has put in.

Initially, in many-- we
had religious studies.

All organizations
in all countries

had religious studies, or
they had civic education,
or ethical studies.

But those are out of
the curriculum today,
and I really think it's a pity.

Because the code of
ethics of friendship
gives beyond academics.

Academics is
extremely important.

It has a space, and it
has a place in the world.

It's not the highest
requirement for everything.

And you see, these children,
they can be great then,

but tomorrow, if
they can fully have

a character which is strong,
discipline which is good,

if they have values, you are
making them into human beings,

and you're making them
into good citizens.
And we need that.

And so we have this
code of values.
It's very simple.
The whole world has values.

What we do is we nurture
them systematically

as a lesson every
day, every day.

So one month is a
month of honesty.

And we teach honesty,
what is honesty, stories.
We have gatherings.
We have actions.

Next month, compassion,
empathy, tolerance.
And people internalize this.

Now we have this
throughout every meeting
that we have in the community.

So 500,000 people,
600,000 people

that we touch every month, they
are given this code of ethics.
It's extremely important.
Because very often, values--
every organization has values.
Every company has values.

But very often, it's the
limiting factor for growth.

For friendship,
it's the opposite.

Every decision,
every idea can come

only if it's within the
framework of that value.

I cannot imagine somebody
coming to me and saying,

we need to do
this, but you know,
it might have a gender problem.
Never.
It cannot happen.

They will come to me
saying, this is inclusive.

This is the reason
why we should do it.

And I think this is one of
the core difference of how
we work with values.
